raw_text:
Text message record smashed again
 
 UK mobile owners continue to break records with their text messaging, with latest figures showing that 26 billion texts were sent in total in 2004.
 
 The figures collected by the Mobile Data Association (MDA) showed that 2.4 billion were fired off in December alone, the highest monthly total ever. That was 26% more than in December 2003. The records even surpassed the MDA's own predictions, it said. Every day 78 million messages are sent and there are no signs of a slow down. Before December's bumper text record, the previous highest monthly total was in October 2004, when 2.3 billion were sent. Text messaging is set to smash more records in 2005 too, said the MDA, with forecasts suggesting a total of 30 billion for the year.
 
 Even though mobiles are becoming increasingly sophisticated with much more multimedia applications, texting is still one of the most useful functions of mobiles. People are using SMS to do much more too. Booking cinema tickets, text voting, and news or sports text alerts are growing popular. Mobile owners have also given the chance to donate to the Disasters Emergency Committee's (DEC) Asian Tsunami fund by texting "Donate" to a simple short code number. Looking further ahead in the year, the MDA's chairman Mike Short, has predicted that more people will go online through their mobiles, estimating 15 billion WAP page impressions. Handsets with GPRS capability - an "always on" net connection - will rise to 75%, while 3G mobile ownership growing to five million by the end of 2005. These third generation mobiles offer a high-speed connection which means more data like video can be received on the phone. Globally, mobile phone sales passed 167 million in the third quarter of 2004, according to a recent report from analysts Gartner. That was 26% more than the previous year. It is predicted that there would be two billion handsets in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
llama3.2:1b: UK mobile owners sent 2.4 billion texts in December alone, surpassing the previous record set in October 2004 and forecasted for 2005.
The MDA predicts 30 billion text messages will be sent in 2005.
Texting is still a popular function of mobiles despite increasing sophistication with multimedia applications.
llama3.2:3b: UK mobile owners sent 26 billion texts in total in 2004, with a record 2.4 billion in December.
Mobile messaging continues to rise, with forecasts suggesting a total of 30 billion for 2005 and 167 million handsets sold globally in Q3 2004.
gemma2:2b: In 2004, a total of 26 billion texts were sent, with December seeing record-breaking numbers (2.4 billion).
Texting is becoming increasingly diverse in applications, including booking, voting, news alerts, and charitable donations.
Forecasts predict even higher text volumes in 2005, as well as increased mobile internet usage and smartphone adoption.
Globally, mobile phone sales are booming.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK mobile owners send around 30 billion texts every month now, surpassing their own forecasts and set to hit even higher numbers for next year.
Mobiles are used for many more functions than just text messaging.
Some mobile services let people use their phones as part of their daily routine, like booking cinema tickets or voting on news stories.
The MDA says that while texting remains the most useful function of mobiles, many users also find it fun and convenient to send messages using SMS, or voice calls.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Text messaging continues to surge globally, with forecasts predicting another large increase for 2005.
Despite mobiles becoming increasingly sophisticated, texting remains a popular function.
People book cinema tickets, vote via text messages, and receive news alerts via SMS.
Additionally, handsets with GPRS capability are expected to rise to 75% by the end of 2005, while third-generation mobile ownership is projected to grow to five million units.
qwen2.5:3b: UK mobile text messaging continues to break records with over 26 billion texts sent in 2004, surpassing even predictions.
In December alone, 2.4 billion messages were sent—the highest monthly total ever recorded.
The trend shows no sign of slowing down; by year-end, forecasts suggest a total of 30 billion texts for the year.
Despite more sophisticated mobile features, texting remains popular for functions like booking cinema tickets and text voting.
Mobile owners can also donate to disaster funds through SMS.

The MDA predicts that internet access via mobiles will rise to 15 billion page impressions in 2005, with GPRS capability expected to reach 75% of handsets, and 3G ownership projected at five million by end-2005.
Global mobile phone sales reached over 167 million units in Q3 2004, set to increase to two billion by the end of 2005.

granite3.1-dense:2b: In 2004, UK mobile users sent a record-breaking 26 billion texts, with December alone accounting for 2.4 billion messages—a 26% increase from December 2003 and surpassing the Mobile Data Association's (MDA) forecasts.

Despite increasingly multimedia-capable phones, texting remains a primary function due to its versatility in tasks like booking appointments, voting, receiving news alerts, and donating to disaster relief funds.

The MDA anticipates 30 billion texts sent globally in 2005, with trends indicating a growing prevalence of GPRS-enabled devices (75% by the end of 2005) and a three million increase in 3G mobile ownership.
These advanced phones offer high-speed internet access, enabling more data consumption like video streaming.
Globally, mobile sales reached 167 million in Q3 2004, up 26% from the previous year.
Analyst Gartner predicts that two billion handsets will be in use worldwide by the end of 2005.
